channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: The mortality revolution, and the myth of the market: Books in brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01820-5

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: The mortality revolution, and the myth of the market: Books in brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: How to make the workplace fairer for female researchers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01829-w

Nature marked International Women’s Day by asking readers how to achieve gender equality in science.
item.dc:title: How to make the workplace fairer for female researchers
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.title: EU council’s ‘no pay’ publishing model draws mixed response
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01810-7

Some academics have welcomed the proposed open-access plans. But publishing-industry representatives warn they are unrealistic and lack detail.
item.dc:title: EU council’s ‘no pay’ publishing model draws mixed response
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.title: Publisher Correction: Targeting PD-L2–RGMb overcomes microbiome-related immunotherapy resistance
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06237-8

Publisher Correction: Targeting PD-L2–RGMb overcomes microbiome-related immunotherapy resistance
item.dc:title: Publisher Correction: Targeting PD-L2–RGMb overcomes microbiome-related immunotherapy resistance

Nature, Published online: 01 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06263-6

Author Correction: Single-neuronal predictions of others’ beliefs in humans

item.title: This infinite tiling pattern could end a 60-year mathematical quest
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01801-8

First truly single aperiodic tile discovered that can cover an infinite surface without repeating itself.
item.dc:title: This infinite tiling pattern could end a 60-year mathematical quest
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: A storm is whirling atop Uranus
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01767-7

Strongly flowing winds are detected inside a bright spot at the giant planet’s north pole.
item.dc:title: A storm is whirling atop Uranus

item.title: Arab world's first asteroid hopper will visit seven space rocks
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01806-3

UAE's MBR Explorer aims to solve mystery of ultra-red celestial body in the asteroid belt beyond Mars.
item.dc:title: Arab world's first asteroid hopper will visit seven space rocks
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: Biggest ever study of primate genomes has surprises for humanity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01776-6

Genomes of humans' closest relatives provide insight for conservation, human disease and the origins of social structures.
item.dc:title: Biggest ever study of primate genomes has surprises for humanity
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis

item.title: Preprint clubs: why it takes a village to do peer review
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01819-y

A group of early-career researchers have harnessed cross-institutional journal clubs to assess and review immunology preprints.
item.dc:title: Preprint clubs: why it takes a village to do peer review
item.dc:creator: Felix Clemens Richter
Ester Gea-Mallorquí
Arthur Mortha
Nicolas Ruffin
Nicolas Vabret

item.title: Daily briefing: We are exceeding the limits of Earth’s ability to support us
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01821-4

Humanity has crossed eight of nine ‘Earth-system boundaries’ for a healthy and fair world. Plus, the brain’s wrinkles help to drive how it works and an infinite tiling pattern that could end a 60-year mathematical quest.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: We are exceeding the limits of Earth’s ability to support us
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Thousands of early-career NIH researchers forming union for first time
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01845-w

US push for better pay and benefits among scientists arrives at world’s largest biomedical funder.
item.dc:title: Thousands of early-career NIH researchers forming union for first time
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Global plan for dealing with next pandemic just got weaker, critics say
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01805-4

Watered-down language in the latest draft of the ‘pandemic treaty’ worries researchers.
item.dc:title: Global plan for dealing with next pandemic just got weaker, critics say
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Author Correction: Short tRNA anticodon stem and mutant eRF1 allow stop codon reassignment
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06260-9

Author Correction: Short tRNA anticodon stem and mutant eRF1 allow stop codon reassignment
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Short tRNA anticodon stem and mutant eRF1 allow stop codon reassignment

A broadband thermal emission spectrum of the ultra-hot Jupiter WASP-18b

item.title: AI identifies gene interactions to speed up search for treatment targets
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01803-6

How an AI overcomes data-scarcity to map gene networks, and assessing the impact of rocket noise on wildlife.
item.dc:title: AI identifies gene interactions to speed up search for treatment targets
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe
Benjamin Thompson

item.title: Transannular C–H functionalization of cycloalkane carboxylic acids
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06000-z

Quinuclidine-pyridone and sulfonamide-pyridone ligands enable transannular γ-methylene C–H arylation of cycloalkane carboxylic acids with a range of ring sizes, bringing us closer to molecular editing of saturated carbocycles.
item.dc:title: Transannular C–H functionalization of cycloalkane carboxylic acids
item.dc:creator: Guowei Kang
Daniel A. Strassfeld
Tao Sheng
Chia-Yu Chen
Jin-Quan Yu

item.title: Deterministic evolution and stringent selection during preneoplasia
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06102-8

We model occult preneoplasia by biallelic inactivation of TP53, a common early event in gastric cancer, in human gastric organoids, the results implying predictability in the earliest stages of tumorigenesis.
item.dc:title: Deterministic evolution and stringent selection during preneoplasia
item.dc:creator: Kasper Karlsson
Moritz J. Przybilla

item.title: Axonemal structures reveal mechanoregulatory and disease mechanisms
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06140-2

Detailed atomic models of axonemes from algal flagella and human respiratory cilia, which are hair-like protrusions from cells that enable motility and clear mucus from human airways, could provide insights into how they function.
item.dc:title: Axonemal structures reveal mechanoregulatory and disease mechanisms
item.dc:creator: Travis Walton
Miao Gui
Simona Velkova
Mahmoud R. Fassad

Alan Brown

item.title: Attosecond electron microscopy of sub-cycle optical dynamics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06074-9

The cycles of laser light have been used to advance transmission electron microscopy to attosecond time resolution, revealing the interactions between light and matter in terms of their fundamental dimensions in space and time.
item.dc:title: Attosecond electron microscopy of sub-cycle optical dynamics
item.dc:creator: David Nabben
Joel Kuttruff
Levin Stolz
Andrey Ryabov
Peter Baum

item.title: Expertise increases planning depth in human gameplay
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06124-2

A computational model based on a heuristic value function and forward search algorithm predicts human choices, response times and eye movements in games of games of four-in-a-row, and shows evidence for increased planning and improved attention with increased expertise.
item.dc:title: Expertise increases planning depth in human gameplay
item.dc:creator: Bas van Opheusden
Ionatan Kuperwajs
Gianni Galbiati
Zahy Bnaya
Yunqi Li
Wei Ji Ma

item.title: Uncovering the Ediacaran phosphorus cycle
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06077-6

Reconstruction of oceanic phosphorus concentrations during a large negative carbon-isotope excursion co-occurring with global oceanic oxygenation and evolution of some of Earth’s earliest animals suggests that decoupled phosphorus and ocean anoxia cycles during the Ediacaran may have prolonged the rise of atmospheric oxygen.
item.dc:title: Uncovering the Ediacaran phosphorus cycle
item.dc:creator: Matthew S. Dodd

item.title: A pan-influenza antibody inhibiting neuraminidase via receptor mimicry
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06136-y

The neuraminidase-targeting monoclonal antibody FNI9 potently inhibits the enzymatic activity of influenza A and B viruses via receptor mimicry.
item.dc:title: A pan-influenza antibody inhibiting neuraminidase via receptor mimicry
item.dc:creator: Corey Momont

item.title: Increasingly negative tropical water–interannual CO<sub>2</sub> growth rate coupling
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06056-x

Records show that tropical water availability rather than temperature appears to have been increasingly controlling the interannual variability of the terrestrial carbon cycle over the past 59 years.
item.dc:title: Increasingly negative tropical water–interannual CO<sub>2</sub> growth rate coupling
item.dc:creator: Laibao Liu
Philippe Ciais
Mengxi Wu
Ryan S. Padrón
Pierre Friedlingstein

Sonia I. Seneviratne

item.title: Characterization of just one atom using synchrotron X-rays
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06011-w

Using a specialized tip as a detector, the fingerprints of a single atom of iron and terbium are observed in synchrotron X-ray absorption spectra, allowing elemental and chemical characterization one atom at a time.
item.dc:title: Characterization of just one atom using synchrotron X-rays
item.dc:creator: Tolulope M. Ajayi

item.title: Enhanced rare-earth separation with a metal-sensitive lanmodulin dimer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05945-5

A study biochemically and structurally characterizes a lanmodulin from Hansschlegelia quercus with an oligomeric state sensitive to rare-earth ionic radius.
item.dc:title: Enhanced rare-earth separation with a metal-sensitive lanmodulin dimer
item.dc:creator: Joseph A. Mattocks
Jonathan J. Jung
Chi-Yun Lin
Ziye Dong

Joseph A. Cotruvo Jr

item.title: Transfer learning enables predictions in network biology
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06139-9

A context-aware, attention-based deep learning model pretrained on single-cell transcriptomes enables predictions in settings with limited data in network biology and could accelerate discovery of key network regulators and candidate therapeutic targets.
item.dc:title: Transfer learning enables predictions in network biology
item.dc:creator: Christina V. Theodoris
Ling Xiao
Anant Chopra
Mark D. Chaffin
Zeina R. Al Sayed

Zexian Zeng

Patrick T. Ellinor

item.title: Strong and ductile titanium–oxygen–iron alloys by additive manufacturing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05952-6

Combining alloy design with additive manufacturing process design creates α–β titanium–oxygen–iron alloys that are both strong and ductile, with the potential to revitalize off-grade sponge titanium and thereby reduce the carbon footprint of the titanium industry.
item.dc:title: Strong and ductile titanium–oxygen–iron alloys by additive manufacturing
item.dc:creator: Tingting Song

Ma Qian

item.title: In situ tumour arrays reveal early environmental control of cancer immunity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06132-2

Skin tumour array by microporation (STAMP) captures the dynamic relationships of spatial, cellular and molecular components of tumour rejection and has the potential to translate therapeutic concepts into successful clinical strategies.
item.dc:title: In situ tumour arrays reveal early environmental control of cancer immunity
item.dc:creator: Guadalupe Ortiz-Muñoz

item.title: Myelin dysfunction drives amyloid-β deposition in models of Alzheimer’s disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06120-6

Mouse models show that myelin dysfunction and associated inflammation increase with age, which can promote amyloid-β deposition and therefore risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease.
item.dc:title: Myelin dysfunction drives amyloid-β deposition in models of Alzheimer’s disease
item.dc:creator: Constanze Depp

item.title: The effects of cash transfers on adult and child mortality in low- and middle-income countries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06116-2

A survey of mortality data from low- and middle-income countries shows that government-led cash transfer programmes are associated with decreased mortality among women and children under five years of age.
item.dc:title: The effects of cash transfers on adult and child mortality in low- and middle-income countries
item.dc:creator: Aaron Richterman
Christophe Millien
Elizabeth F. Bair
Gregory Jerome
Jean Christophe Dimitri Suffrin
Jere R. Behrman
Harsha Thirumurthy

item.title: Pan-KRAS inhibitor disables oncogenic signalling and tumour growth
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06123-3

A non-covalent inhibitor that binds preferentially to the inactive state of KRAS while sparing NRAS and HRAS is reported, indicating that most KRAS oncoproteins cycle between an active state and an inactive state in cancer cells.
item.dc:title: Pan-KRAS inhibitor disables oncogenic signalling and tumour growth

item.title: Indefinite and bidirectional near-infrared nanocrystal photoswitching
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06076-7

This study reports unlimited near-infrared photoswitching in inorganic avalanching nanoparticles via a discrete shift of threshold intensity mediated by internal defect-based colour centres.
item.dc:title: Indefinite and bidirectional near-infrared nanocrystal photoswitching
item.dc:creator: Changhwan Lee

item.title: Nuclear export of pre-60S particles through the nuclear pore complex
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06128-y

We report the cryo-electron microscopy structure of native pre-60S particles trapped in the channel of the yeast nuclear pore complex, suggesting a translocation model for the export of pre-60S particles through the complex.
item.dc:title: Nuclear export of pre-60S particles through the nuclear pore complex
item.dc:creator: Zongqiang Li
Shuaijiabin Chen

Sen-Fang Sui

item.title: Hallmarks of transcriptional intratumour heterogeneity across a thousand tumours
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06130-4

A study identifies 41 consensus gene expression meta-programs that are coordinately upregulated in subpopulations of malignant cells across tumour types, providing a comprehensive picture of hallmarks of intratumour heterogeneity.
item.dc:title: Hallmarks of transcriptional intratumour heterogeneity across a thousand tumours
item.dc:creator: Avishai Gavish

item.title: Safe and just Earth system boundaries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06083-8

We find that justice considerations constrain the integrated Earth system boundaries more than safety considerations for climate and atmospheric aerosol loading, and our assessment provides a foundation for safeguarding the global commons for all people.
item.dc:title: Safe and just Earth system boundaries

item.title: Geometric constraints on human brain function
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06098-1

Cortical and subcortical activity can be parsimoniously understood as resulting from excitations of fundamental, resonant modes of the brain’s geometry rather than from modes of complex interregional connectivity.
item.dc:title: Geometric constraints on human brain function
item.dc:creator: James C. Pang
Kevin M. Aquino
Marianne Oldehinkel
Peter A. Robinson
Ben D. Fulcher
Michael Breakspear
Alex Fornito

item.title: Engineered tRNAs suppress nonsense mutations in cells and in vivo
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06133-1

Suppressor tRNAs adapted to the amino acid that they carry enable readthrough of premature termination codons introduced by nonsense mutations and show potential for the treatment of genetic diseases such as cystic fibrosis.
item.dc:title: Engineered tRNAs suppress nonsense mutations in cells and in vivo
item.dc:creator: Suki Albers
Elizabeth C. Allen
Nikhil Bharti
Marcos Davyt

Carlos G. Perez-Garcia

Priya Karmali
Daiki Matsuda
Eric J. Sorscher
Pad Chivukula
Zoya Ignatova

item.title: The geometry of the human brain shapes its function
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01495-y

Brain activity is structured in space and time. The resulting activity patterns are conventionally thought to depend on an intricate web of anatomical connections that link specialized populations of cells. This work challenges this paradigm by showing that macroscale neuronal dynamics of the human brain are fundamentally shaped by its physical geometry.
item.dc:title: The geometry of the human brain shapes its function

item.title: Our mutual friend, the prediction algorithm
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01752-0

It does the thinking, so you don’t have to.
item.dc:title: Our mutual friend, the prediction algorithm
item.dc:creator: Andrew Kozma

item.title: AI intensifies fight against ‘paper mills’ that churn out fake research
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01780-w

Text- and image-generating tools present a new hurdle for efforts to tackle the growing number of fake papers making their way into the academic literature.
item.dc:title: AI intensifies fight against ‘paper mills’ that churn out fake research
item.dc:creator: Layal Liverpool

item.title: Cash-transfer programmes reduce mortality in low- and middle-income countries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01507-x

Cash-transfer programmes have emerged as central components of poverty-reduction strategies in many countries, and became even more common during the COVID-19 pandemic. An analysis of 37 low- and middle-income countries finds that these programmes led to marked reductions in population-level mortality in adult women and young children.
item.dc:title: Cash-transfer programmes reduce mortality in low- and middle-income countries

item.title: Search for distant atmosphere off to a rocky start
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01738-y

Astronomers have used observations of infrared light to measure the heat emanating from an Earth-sized exoplanet known as TRAPPIST-1b. Their findings reveal that the planet is a bare rock, devoid of any atmosphere.
item.dc:title: Search for distant atmosphere off to a rocky start
item.dc:creator: Laura Kreidberg

item.title: Surgical wonders and dodgy medical ethics: the Hunterian Museum reopens
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01736-0

The London museum is a treasure chest of medical specimens both fascinating and ghoulish — now with a renewed focus on questions about how its collections came to be.
item.dc:title: Surgical wonders and dodgy medical ethics: the Hunterian Museum reopens
item.dc:creator: Nisha Gaind

item.title: How to define unjust planetary change
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01743-1

Biophysical and sociopolitical factors have been integrated into a set of measures of planetary change that aim to pinpoint safe and just thresholds for all living things. The exercise is immensely ambitious and inevitably challenging.
item.dc:title: How to define unjust planetary change
item.dc:creator: Stephen Humphreys

item.title: How a protein differentiates between rare-earth elements
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01739-x

A protein has been discovered that binds to the lighter members of the rare-earth family of metals more strongly than to the heavier ones — an amazing feat, given the chemical similarities of these elements.
item.dc:title: How a protein differentiates between rare-earth elements
item.dc:creator: Scott Banta

item.title: The human brain’s characteristic wrinkles help to drive how it works
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01774-8

A model of the brain’s geometry better explains neuronal activity than a model based on the ‘connectome’.
item.dc:title: The human brain’s characteristic wrinkles help to drive how it works
item.dc:creator: Davide Castelvecchi

item.title: Patterns of tumour transcriptional variability
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01744-0

The compilation and analysis of a compendium of single-cell RNA-sequencing studies across various cancers reveals recurring gene-expression programs that underpin tumour heterogeneity.
item.dc:title: Patterns of tumour transcriptional variability
item.dc:creator: Raymond W. S. Ng
Sydney M. Shaffer

item.title: A structural model of the core of cilia
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01501-3

Axonemes are molecular machines that enable the movement of cilia, the hair-like structures found on the surface of some cells. Atomic models of axonemes from the flagella of green algae and from the cilia of human respiratory-tract cells reveal how the axoneme enables the cilia to move, and explain the effects of genetic mutations that cause human ciliary disease.
item.dc:title: A structural model of the core of cilia

item.title: Daily briefing: Surveying the lush mosses of Canada’s Great Bear Rainforest
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01808-1

In a ‘bioblitz’, scientists catalogue the incredible diversity of bryophytes in a temperate rain forest. Plus, a ‘loss and damage’ fund for biodiversity and how chemists can now edit molecule cores atom by atom.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Surveying the lush mosses of Canada’s Great Bear Rainforest
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Machine-learning model makes predictions about network biology
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01504-0

A deep-learning model called Geneformer has been developed and pretrained using about 30 million single-cell gene-expression profiles to enable it to make predictions about gene-network biology in instances in which gene-expression data are limited. Geneformer can be tuned for many downstream applications to accelerate discovery of key gene-network regulators and candidate therapeutic targets.
item.dc:title: Machine-learning model makes predictions about network biology

item.title: ‘Almost magical’: chemists can now move single atoms in and out of a molecule’s core
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01735-1

An explosion of skeletal editing methods to insert, delete or swap individual atoms in molecular backbones could accelerate drug discovery.
item.dc:title: ‘Almost magical’: chemists can now move single atoms in and out of a molecule’s core
item.dc:creator: Mark Peplow

item.title: Why ideas of ‘planetary boundaries’ must uphold environmental justice
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01749-9

Earth-system boundaries define a safe operating space for humanity. Accounting for the planet’s most vulnerable people provides a stark warning of the work still to be done.'
item.dc:title: Why ideas of ‘planetary boundaries’ must uphold environmental justice

item.title: India cuts periodic table and evolution from school textbooks — experts are baffled
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01770-y

Nature has learnt that the periodic table, as well as evolution, won’t be taught to under-16s as they start the new school year.
item.dc:title: India cuts periodic table and evolution from school textbooks — experts are baffled
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis

item.title: Designer titanium alloys created using 3D printing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01360-y

An original class of strong, ductile titanium alloy containing the inexpensive and abundant oxygen and iron as principal alloying elements has been created using 3D printing. The research findings offer promise for turning low‑quality titanium sponge — a waste product of the energy-intensive production of titanium — into high‑performance titanium alloys, and for innovative alloy engineering.
item.dc:title: Designer titanium alloys created using 3D printing

item.title: Satellite imagery identifies deliberate attacks on hospitals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01759-7

Satellite imagery identifies deliberate attacks on hospitals
item.dc:title: Satellite imagery identifies deliberate attacks on hospitals
item.dc:creator: Danielle N. Poole
Nathaniel A. Raymond
Kaveh Khoshnood

item.title: Electricity outages delay SDGs in sub-Saharan Africa
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01757-9

Electricity outages delay SDGs in sub-Saharan Africa
item.dc:title: Electricity outages delay SDGs in sub-Saharan Africa
item.dc:creator: Qian Jia
Ying Wang
Zhenci Xu
Fengting Li

item.title: I use a robot to restore Pompeii’s shattered frescoes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01741-3

Cultural and heritage researcher Arianna Traviglia uses robotic technology to painstakingly reconstruct 2,000-year-old mural paintings in Pompeii.
item.dc:title: I use a robot to restore Pompeii’s shattered frescoes
item.dc:creator: Stav Dimitropoulos

item.title: Marine heatwaves: base definitions on ecosystem damage
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01758-8

Marine heatwaves: base definitions on ecosystem damage
item.dc:title: Marine heatwaves: base definitions on ecosystem damage
item.dc:creator: Tiantian Li
Shilu Tong
Xiaoming Shi

item.title: From the archive: foods of the future and cryptography secrets
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01742-2

Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.dc:title: From the archive: foods of the future and cryptography secrets

item.title: A tool for optimizing messenger RNA sequence
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01745-z

With messenger RNA therapeutics being developed for uses beyond vaccines, problems of RNA instability must be addressed. A new algorithm optimizes mRNA sequence for both stability and the encoding of amino acids.
item.dc:title: A tool for optimizing messenger RNA sequence
item.dc:creator: Anna K. Blakney

item.title: Why is India dropping evolution and the periodic table from school science?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01750-2

India’s curriculum body needs to explain why it has removed foundational topics from school textbooks.
item.dc:title: Why is India dropping evolution and the periodic table from school science?

item.title: Why the world needs more transparency on the origins of novel pathogens
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01722-6

Collaboration and openness are essential to minimize the risks of future pandemics, says the World Health Organization’s scientific advisory group, SAGO.
item.dc:title: Why the world needs more transparency on the origins of novel pathogens
item.dc:creator: Marietjie Venter

item.title: Daily briefing: Robots reconstruct Pompeii frescoes from thousands of fragments
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01781-9

A robot equipped with soft humanoid arms helps to reconstruct Pompeii’s shattered frescoes. Plus, anonymous peer review equalizes the publishing playing field and why California condors will be vaccinated against avian flu.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Robots reconstruct Pompeii frescoes from thousands of fragments
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Why I’m leading Pacific Islands students in the fight on climate change
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01751-1

Our voices were crucial in persuading UN states to back legal obligations to act on climate change. Here’s how we did it.
item.dc:title: Why I’m leading Pacific Islands students in the fight on climate change
item.dc:creator: Cynthia Houniuhi

item.title: Turkey’s researchers fear loss of freedom after Erdoğan re-elected
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 30 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01775-7

Researchers expect the administration to further restrict autonomy and free speech. Some say they will migrate or retire.
item.dc:title: Turkey’s researchers fear loss of freedom after Erdoğan re-elected
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: How to lock away more carbon: give mangroves a little love
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 29 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01765-9

Restored mangroves and seagrass meadows could suck more carbon from the atmosphere.
item.dc:title: How to lock away more carbon: give mangroves a little love

item.title: Author Correction: Testosterone histories from tusks reveal woolly mammoth musth episodes
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06242-x

Author Correction: Testosterone histories from tusks reveal woolly mammoth musth episodes
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Testosterone histories from tusks reveal woolly mammoth musth episodes

item.title: Camera that could fit on a penny captures vivid colour photos
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01764-w

A ‘meta-lens’ and corrective algorithms allow a tiny device to produce high-resolution images.
item.dc:title: Camera that could fit on a penny captures vivid colour photos

item.title: Audio long read: Can giant surveys of scientists fight misinformation on COVID, climate change and more?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01706-6

Hoping to improve public debate and policymaking, multiple efforts have been launched to gather researchers' consensus views.
item.dc:title: Audio long read: Can giant surveys of scientists fight misinformation on COVID, climate change and more?
item.dc:creator: David Adam
Benjamin Thompson

item.title: Daily briefing: Why stress worsens inflammatory bowel disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01778-4

Brain cues produced by chronic stress lead to a cascade of events that eventually triggers immune cells in the gut. Plus, a key database that will guide deep-sea mining might be flawed and ‘tree islands’ can blunt the harm of oil-palm plantations.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Why stress worsens inflammatory bowel disease
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: China is using satellites to police the protection of nature — but will it work?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01714-6

Scientists say the system will help safeguard nature, but they want more transparency about the zones chosen for conservation.
item.dc:title: China is using satellites to police the protection of nature — but will it work?
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis

item.title: To diversify the scientific workforce, postdoc recruitment needs a rethink
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 26 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01740-4

Biased hiring practices are limiting efforts to attract and retain researchers of colour.
item.dc:title: To diversify the scientific workforce, postdoc recruitment needs a rethink
item.dc:creator: Esther Landhuis
